page.title: 13The Chemic Painthorpe
page.content: The Chemic Painthorpe got its name from the industries in the area in the 18th century. In 1841 Painthorpe was the centre of the local clay fire and terra cotta works.Fire and clay was worked by open cast methods in pits. The brickworks tramway extended to the Calder and Heble Navigation Canal near Broad Cut Low Lock Calder Grove the Crigglestone clay and fire company changed hands several times before closing in 1887.The only evidence to be seen in 1985 of this industry is three concrete posts where the shafts used to be in a field at the end of Daw Green Lane.
